Posts.Content: Hi Mark. I selected my surgeon even though he was relatively inexperienced ( little less than 300 surgeries) and not yet board certified. Why? PHD/MD Stanford, 6 th. Year resident at Mass General in Boston (high volume, nationally recognized hospital). Instructor in surgery at Harvard medical school. I was his last patient before he left for fellowship at Sloan Kettering in NYC. After meeting him, I decided his qualifications outweighed his “inexperience “. My point is just don’t look at total # of surgeries.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Rising psa with 2 negative biopsies. MRI Prads 5. 5/30/2018, 3T fusion biopsy resulted in Gleason score 4+3. Laparoscopic radical prostatectomy on 6/14/2018 Pathology report: Gleason 4+5, with tertiary grade 3 confined to gland. Grade group 5. Seminal vesicles neg. bladder neck margin, right apex, lymph nodes neg. pTNM stage: p T2 NO Prostate weight:51g. 70% involved by tumor. EPE NEG. LVI NEG. Perineural invasion present. 3 month PSA: <0.1 ng/ml 6 month PSA: <0.1 ng/ml

Posts.Content: Minutes before my biopsies a lidocaine jell was applied to the area. After this took effect, the numbing agent was injected through the rectum wall. I wouldn’t say the injections were painless, but they were tolerable.

Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic You usually get the path results of each lymph node removed as part of the post-RP path report, which covers all tissue removed. Each sample examined will be labeled what it is and what it showed. (In some cases of advanced cancer one has lymph nodes removed before the RP, in which case you would get that LN report separately.) Thank you very much for the information. In general, do you know how long after surgery I can expect to hear the results?
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Rising psa with 2 negative biopsies. MRI Prads 5. 5/30/2018, 3T fusion biopsy resulted in Gleason score 4+3. Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Yes, I had my last biopsy 2 weeks before surgery and prostate was swollen at time of surgery. Made nerve sparing surgery more time consuming, as well as lab evaluation of some tissue samples taken during surgery (negative).ï¿½ï¿½ surgeon weighed waiting a few more weeks for prostate to “calm down” against 2 false negative biopsies, And Gleason 4+3 score. Either that, or he just wanted to put in some overtime.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Posts.Content: Psa result was included in pre op blood work
Posts.Title: Psa result

Posts.Content: My psa level 1 week after 16 core biopsy rose from 9.5 to 25.0. Is this unusual? Biopsy positive. Gleason 4+3. Scheduled for laparoscopic prostatectomy next week
Posts.Title: Psa result

Posts.Content: Hi Sean. I used the large bag all week. Never have to disconnect/clean it. Kept bag in small bucket with handle, and when walking outside just put it in shopping bag. Hung bag on bed rail when sleeping. Worked great. Don’t freak out re: rose colored urine. Only takes 1-2 drops of blood to cause that. Don’t forget to take stool softener as directed.
Posts.Signature: 65 years old. Rising psa with 2 negative biopsies. MRI Prads 5. 5/30/2018, 3T fusion biopsy resulted in Gleason score 4+3. Perineural invasion present. 3 month PSA: <0.1 ng/ml 6 month PSA: <0.1 ng/ml

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee We found those horseshoe shaped travel neck cushions work just as well. I experienced perineal soreness for about 4 weeks post op. OTC painkillers seemed to offer relief.

Posts.Title: Sore bottom still, 2-1/2 wks post RALP?

Posts.Content: Results from biopsy: Gleason 4+3. Meeting Monday to discuss treatment
Posts.Title: Biopsy concerns

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark H. Thanks. Ya I guess I thought the urine bag was looking lighter for awhile - it only been two days since the surgery (on Tuesday morning, I write this Thursday evening). I guess I will have to wait for more information. But I am glad its over (at least for now). I had some days where the urine in my catheter bag would turn pink. This seemed to coincide with increased physical activity (walking). When I questioned this, I was told it was normal, as only one or two drops of blood would color the urine. If it turned bright red, I would contact your urologist.

Posts.Title: 2nd day postop

Posts.Content: Hi guys. Scheduled for my third prostate biopsy tomorrow. Had one regular (awake), one saturation (asleep), both negative. Then rising psa - last one 9.5. Had mri which indicates tumor specific region p-rads 5. So had 3T mri for fusion biopsy tomorrow. Concerned about biopsy pain and of course results
Posts.Title: Biopsy concerns

Posts.Content: Prostate Gland Size: The prostate gland measures 4.2 cm AP x 5.5 cm transverse x 4.2 cm craniocaudad consistent with a prostatic gland volume of 48.0 cc. Central Zone: No tumor-suspicious regions are identified in the central zone. Transition Zone: There is a tumor suspicious region, PI-RADS 5, involving the anterior right aspect of the transition zone at the base. This extends inferiorly to the mid gland. This measures 2.1 x 2.7 x 1.7 cm. This demonstrates non-circumscribed moderate T2 shortening and evidence of restricted diffusion with early arterial enhancement. There is some nodular enlargement and inhomogeneous signal intensity throughout the transition zone most commonly due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. No tumor-suspicious region is identified within the transition zone. Peripheral Zone: No tumor-suspicious regions are identified in the peripheral zone. Extraprostatic Extension: None. Seminal Vesicle Invasion: None. Pelvic Lymphadenopathy: None. Urinary Bladder: Trabeculated urinary bladder. No evidence for mass. Rectosigmoid Colon: There is no evidence of diverticulitis or diverticulosis. No rectosigmoid mass is identified. No rectal hemorrhoids are seen. No inguinal hernia is identified. Pelvic Osseous Structures: There is no evidence of osseous metastatic disease at the level of the prostate gland. IMPRESSION: 1. The prostate gland volume equals 48.0 cc. 2. The PSA density not given. 3. There is mild nodular enlargement and inhomogeneous signal intensity throughout the transition zone most commonly due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. 4. There is a tumor suspicious region, PI-RADS 5, involving the anterior right aspect of the transition zone at the base. 5. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension of prostate cancer, seminal vesicle invasion or pelvic lymphadenopathy.
Posts.Title: Biopsy concerns

Posts.Content: Hi Max. I had my surgery 2 weeks after receiving my biopsy results ( Gleason 7). I chose laparoscopic instead of robotic because that would have pushed back surgery date another month. My doctor assured me he was proficient in both. With my post surgery Gleason score upgraded to 9 (4+5), and Psa still undetectable at 6 months, I feel confident that I made the right decision.

Posts.Title: Time to Schedule Surgery

Posts.Content: I have had biopsies both ways. My second biopsy was a “saturation biopsy “ and my urologist recommended anasthesia. ( by the way, this biopsy missed the cancer that was later found). If your upcoming biopsy is more extensive, perhaps anesthesia is a good choice.
